newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Bogota hotels feel effect of rebel violence.
newsitem.headline: Bogota hotels feel effect of rebel violence.

text.p: Reservations at Bogota's most exclusive hotels have plummeted as foreign businessmen canceled travel plans in the face of spiraling guerrilla violence, one of Colombia's leading daily newspapers reported on Sunday.
The Bogota Hotel Association, which represents 20 four- and five-star establishments, said bookings from abroad -- mostly international businessmen -- had fallen by more than one-third.
If the trend continues, hotels affiliated to the organization say they will lose 8,000 bookings worth 1.6 billion pesos ($1.6 million) in the next two weeks, El Espectador said.

"Colombia's image abroad has suffered because of the negative media coverage. Tourists are frightened when they hear about the law and order situation here," association chairman Edgar Garzon Saboya said.
But the leader of another hotel organization played down Garzon's claims, saying the main problem was one of excess supply not reduced demand.
Ismael Enrique Arciniegas told El Espectador that in the first half of this year, hotel bookings rose by almost 10 percent while the number of hotel rooms available grew by 40 percent.
